title: Can I make my guitar sound like a ukulele? - Quora

response.answer_text: Depends on what kind of guitar you have. As Thomas Sowers said, if you have a classical guitar, you can put a capo at position five and you’ll get something that approximates a standard ukulele. It won’t sound exactly like a uke, because a classical guitar has a much larger body and a deeper bass response, but it will get you close enough to ‘fake’ it through a song. You don’t have to take off the low E and A strings, btw, just don’t play those! Taking off the D string, and replacing it with another high E string would let you tune it up an octave to simulate the ukulele’s characteristic re-entrant tuning. Yes, you “could” put nylon strings on a steel string acoustic guitar, but I really don’t think that make sense. For $20 you can get a “plunker” ukulele, and that’s probably a better real “answer” here.

You could cut the neck down and snap a string? Just kidding - if you really wanted a ukelele sound I’d recommend testing out different pedal settings or hooking yourself into DAW software where you can mess with virtual pedals. It can definitely be done if you have the time and the patience! But then again, maybe just by a ukelele? They’re not expensive!

Depends on how accurate you need to be. I once wrote a reggae ukulele part for a song one of my bands did, that was really essential to the groove. We liked to play it live, and I didn’t want to bring a ukulele just for one song, so I’d play it on electric guitar. Exact same notes, very different sound.

Take off the lowest strings (E and A). Put nylon strings on it. Put a capo at the 5th fret. That’s about it, but you can take it a step further by putting the same size string on the lowest string as you would the highest string and tune that to high G. That’s how I learned before getting an actual ukulele.
Put your capo on the 5th fret, and then only use the lowest (in pitch) strings as if they were ukulele strings.
